perturbation.original_text: 16.2.4. If we do not exercise our rights to purchase your Delivery Vehicle(s), you must immediately make such modifications or alterations to the Delivery Vehicle(s) that may be needed to remove any Proprietary Marks and to otherwise distinguish the appearance of the vehicle(s) from those used by other Restaurants.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.2.4. If we do not exercise our rights to purchase your Delivery Vehicle(s), you are encouraged to consider making modifications or alterations to the Delivery Vehicle(s).
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires franchisees to remove Proprietary Marks from delivery vehicles if the franchisor does not purchase them. The modified text makes this action optional ('encouraged to consider'), creating a contradiction if Proprietary Marks are still being used without authorization as previously defined in the contract.

perturbation.original_text: 3.7. Delinquency. If any Royalties or other amounts owed to us are not paid in full by the due date, we have the right to charge interest on the overdue amount at the rate of one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month (or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law, if less than 1.5%) from the date such amount was due until paid in full. Unpaid interest charges will compound annually. In addition, we will have the right to charge a late fee for each occurrence of a payment that is more than 30 days past due, which fee will be $100 for the first such occurrence, $200 for the second such occurrence, and $300 for the third and each subsequent occurrence during the Term of this Agreement. The late fee is to compensate us for our administrative costs incurred in enforcing your obligation to pay us.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.7. Delinquency. If any Royalties or other amounts owed to us are not paid in full by the due date, we may, at our discretion, charge interest on the overdue amount. In addition, we may have the right to charge a late fee for each occurrence of a payment that is more than 30 days past due. The late fee is to compensate us for our administrative costs incurred in enforcing your obligation to pay us.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies the exact interest rate and late fee amounts for delinquent payments. The modified text removes these specific amounts and makes the imposition of interest and late fees discretionary, creating uncertainty and potential for disputes over what constitutes a 'reasonable' interest rate or late fee.

perturbation.original_text:
6.19.1. Types and Amounts of Coverage. Throughout the entire Term, you must maintain such types of insurance, in such amounts, as we may require. Such insurance is in addition to any other insurance that may be required by applicable law, your landlord, or otherwise. Policies that we require must be written by an insurance company reasonably satisfactory to us with an A.M. Best rating of “A” or better, and, must name us as an additional insured party. At a minimum, such policies must include the following:
(a) commercial general liability insurance, completed-operations and independent-contractors coverage in the amount of
$1,000,000, per person/per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage combined with a general aggregate of $3,000,000.
(b) workers’-compensation coverage in the amount of at least $100,000/$500,000/$100,000, unemployment insurance and
employer’s liability insurance, as well as such other insurance as may be required by statute or rule of the state in which the Franchised Business is
located;
(c) fire, lightning, vandalism, theft, malicious mischief, flood (if in a special flood-hazard area), sprinkler damage, and the
perils described in ex-tended-coverage insurance with primary and excess limits of not less than the full-replacement value of the supplies, furniture,
fixtures, equipment, machinery, inventory, and plate glass having a deductible of not more than $1,000 and naming us as a loss payee;
(d) automobile liability insurance-including coverage of vehicles not owned by you, but used by employees in
connection with the Franchised Business, with a combination of primary and excess limits of not less than $1,000,000;
(e) commercial blanket bond in the amount of $100,000; and
(f) such other insurance, in such amounts, as we reasonably require for our and your protection.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.19.1. Types and Amounts of Coverage. Throughout the entire Term, you must maintain insurance, at our discretion, in necessary amounts, as we may require. Policies that we require must be written by an insurance company reasonably satisfactory to us with an A.M. Best rating of “A” or better, and, must name us as an additional insured party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text sets specific minimum coverage amounts for various types of insurance. The modified text removes these specific amounts, giving the franchisor greater discretion in determining the 'necessary amounts' of coverage. This creates ambiguity and could lead to disputes over whether the franchisee has adequate insurance, especially because the minimum requirements were removed.
